US Tsubaki
RMP/PSM Program
EPA #1000 0017 3732
1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

U.S. Tsubaki (UST) stores up to 24,264 pounds of propane at the 106 Lonczak Drive site in a 6,565 gallon propane storage tank that is used for heat treating metal. UST is required to address the safety requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) Regulation 40 CFR 68 and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 because UST exceeds the 10,000 pound propane threshold.

The executive summary provides an overview of facility specific information that was generated during the development of the RMP including but not limited to storage quantities, hazard assessment data, training dates, etc.

On November 2, 2007, Tighe & Bond met with facility personnel to audit and update the UST RMP as required under 40 CFR 68.79.  During that audit, we determined that the facility recently installed several pit furnaces that utilize hydrogen, which is co-located and interconnected with the propane and ammonia systems. Although ammonia and hydrogen are below regulatory threshold limits for RMP, the facility performed a process hazard analysis (PHA) of these processes that could affect the propane system on May 13, 2008. The purpose of this PHA was to review the potential hazards of the facility?s pit furnaces and determine corrective actions necessary to maintain the integrity and the safety of the system.

The RMP electronic submittal form was originally submitted and reviewed by EPA on December 19, 2000 and an updated version was re-submitted on September 13, 2004 and February 4, 2009
2.0	MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 
The site specific Risk Management Program Coordinator (RMPC) is Tom Cavanaugh.  Please note that the RMPC is a collective term that refers to the overall RMP program managers as well as anyone these individuals may designate to assist them with the implementation of this program. The

RMPC reviews the following assignments with UST management and assigns responsibilities accordingly.  UST management recognizes assigned responsibilities and provides adequate resources to help ensure compliance.
2.1	RMP Operations Director (Tom Cavanaugh)
The RMP Operations Director oversees the overall process safety of the system to include the following tasks:
* Assigns responsibility to designees to ensure that each RMP task has an accountable individual in-charge
* Coordinates activities with outside consultants or contractors to document compliance with the RMP regulation
* Periodically reviews RMP regulations for changes which would necessitate an update of the hazard assessment and electronic re-submittal to the EPA
* Reviews Management of Change Forms and updates the RMP written program on a periodic basis
* Holds periodic RMP safety meetings with designees to verify compliance with regulations
* Presents the RMP requirements (e.g. designees, manpower, resource costs, etc) to upper management for consideration and approval
* Ensures contractors are pre-approved for work on propane systems
2.2	Training Supervisors (Tom Cavanaugh)
The training supervisor has identified a periodic training schedule, which is generally described in Section 7.0 of the RMP that includes the following:
* Maintains a file on attendance records and course training outlines
* Administration of exams or observations to evaluate employee competency
* Performs awareness training for all affected employees who work on or near the chlorine system (e.g. emergency evacuation, hazard communication, etc.)
* Conducts regular safety meetings involving representative employees to identify, evaluate and correct obvious hazards
2.3	Maintenance Lead (Les Zielinski)
The maintenance supervisor oversees the operation and maintenance of the process (i.e. Mechanical Integrity Program) to include the following:
* Develops maintenance schedules for the facility propane, ammonia, hydrog

en and other critical equipment
* Documents all maintenance activities to ensure compliance with the RMP regulations
* Ensure that only qualified personnel or pre-approved contractors work on the chlorine systems at the facility
* Obtains necessary permits or approvals for system installations or modifications
* Completes Management of Change Forms or Process Hazard Analysis whenever the system is modified
* Maintains manufacturers operations and maintenance manuals for all propane related equipment at the facility
* Ensures that all operating/maintenance personnel and contractors follow standard operating procedures found in the RMP and documents accordingly (e.g. hot work permits, work permits, etc.)
2.4	HAZMAT Team Chiefs (Les Zielinski/Tom Cavanaugh)
The HAZMAT team chiefs oversee the emergency response program at the facility to include the following:
* Ensures that Tier II form (Hazardous Material Inventory) and emergency plans are completed each year and submitted to the state, federal and local emergency planning agencies
* Meets with the fire department or the local HAZMAT team periodically to tour the facility
* Performs mock drills periodically with local, facility and contract emergency response personnel to critique the companies? emergency response system
* Ensures that emergency response employees have an adequate level of initial and annual refresher training (e.g. 8-24 hours) to respond to facility emergencies
* Updates emergency response plan on an annual basis, at a minimum, to include personnel list, phone numbers, etc
* Maintains and inspects emergency response equipment and provides appropriate documentation
* Conducts public notice necessary for RMP compliance
* Handles all public relations for emergency response
2.5	Health and Safety Officer (Tom Norton/ Tom Cavanaugh)
The Health and Safety (H&S) Officer is responsible for understanding RMP regulations which may apply to the facility and assisting line management in complian

ce activities, including but not limited to the following:
* Implementation of the hazard communication program to include container labeling, employee training and maintenance of the MSDS system
* Administration of the lockout/tagout program for control of hazardous energy to include development of procedures for machinery, training and equipment procurement
* Implements personnel protective equipment (PPE) programs (e.g. gloves, respirators, glasses, etc.) to ensure that the proper equipment is selected, employees are trained in the usage of PPE and that the process is documented accordingly
* Administers the confined space program to ensure that all spaces are labeled, employees are trained and that proper entry procedures are followed and documented accordingly
* Establishes fire prevention rules for the facility and ensures that hot work permits are completed for any work performed outside of fire protected areas (e.g. maintenance areas)
* Coordinates fire prevention efforts with the HAZMAT Team Chief and incorporates fire prevention information into the emergency response plan
* Manages the propane safety processes for the facility
* Oversee other programs as necessary to document compliance
* Maintains current written programs for each RMP requirement and reviews, each program annually, at a minimum
3.0	HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The hazard assessment is periodically reviewed and re-submitted to the EPA as necessary.  This hazard assessment also includes maps that delineate the off-site consequence (OCA) analysis. In accordance with EPA policy, hazard assessment and OCA data is not included in the executive summary. Please note that the OCA was updated based on revised latitude measurements supplied by the EPA during a September 1, 2004 inspection.  This updated information was submitted to the EPA.

This OCA information has also been provided to the general public (e.g. Local/State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department/HAZMAT

response team) through correspondence dated August 9, 2000 and a public meeting held on September 5, 2000.  The local agencies also receive a copy of the emergency response plan (periodically upon updating) and Tier II forms (annually).  Emergency personnel are also encouraged to tour the facility periodically to familiarize themselves with chemical hazards at UST.  The LEPC conducted a facility walkthrough on December 5, 2005 and the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection inspected the facility on February 20, 2008.  
4.0	PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION 
Important health and safety information must be readily available for the chemical and processes for a variety of reasons (e.g., emergencies, equipment maintenance, etc.).  A listing of the information is included in Section 4.4 of the RMP.

A significant amount of this information can be found primarily throughout the RMP document.  However, the facility maintains a separate process safety file for RMP documentation at the Facility. This includes the equipment manuals for the Japanese furnaces that have been translated into English.  
5.0	PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS 
An initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed at the facility in 2000.  Appropriate facility employees and outside Consultants were involved in this process.  Methodology used during the PHA was a combination checklist/what-if method, recommended by EPA.  The questions in the checklist were derived from EPA?s ?Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis?, the National Fire Protection Agency 58, ?Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code?, and other sources.  A visual inspection of the covered process was also conducted.  A copy of the facility?s EPA mandated RMP and process safety information were also provided during the PHA for reference purposes. The PHA was updated on September 16, 2005 and May 13, 2008.

A number of PHA items have been completed since 2000.  These are designated as ?Action Complete? or ?AC?.  A num

ber of items require ?No Further Action? or ?NFA? after facility review.  
6.0	OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS 
Standard Operating procedures either existed or were developed for the facility.  These include programs such as lockout/tagout, confined space, hot work permit, propane procedures, etc.  A number of these programs have standard operating procedures and checklist which are requisite for documenting regulatory compliance, particularly for the regulated propane process.  The instructions for completion of the forms are included in the RMP document.  UST completes these forms and maintains documentation in the facility files.  

Tighe & Bond personnel visited the facility on June 18, 2000 to investigate and document standard operating procedures for the hardening furnaces.  Operators at the facility reviewed and commented on draft procedures developed by Tighe & Bond.  The Operators comments are included in the final procedures incorporated into this Risk Management Plan.  The operating procedures were reviewed by the RMPC prior to implementation and are reviewed annually thereafter.  The revisions are incorporated into the RMP document.  The page header and the cover page of the RMP are updated to show the last revision date.
7.0	TRAINING
Individuals who work on the process at the facility have been provided specific training on the hazards of the process as well as the safe and proper operating procedures.  Individuals who have been certified in the process are included in the training certification document found in Section 7.6 of the RMP or other training records.  Any new employees who are expected to operate or work on this process are provided specific operational training and included in the training certification list.

Initial regulatory training was provided on May 30, 2000.  Additional propane hazard and emergency response training was performed on June 27, 2000.  Implementation training was performed in December 2000.  The training outlines and ev

aluation quizzes can be found in the facility?s Process Safety file.  The operators were provided their three year refresher training on propane system operations on September 30 and January 20, 2004.  The next round of refresher training for the operators was performed on January 30, 2008, and included training on hydrogen, ammonia, carbon monoxide and propane.

The facility has a regular training schedule that is shown in Section 7.0 of the RMP.  New employees or contractors receive appropriate training in accordance with Section 7.5 of the RMP (e.g. emergency procedures, hazard communications, etc.).
8.0	MECHANICAL INTEGRITY  
The facility must ensure the integrity of process equipment by determining that the equipment is maintained, designed, installed and operating properly.  The primary emphasis behind mechanical integrity is preventative maintenance.  The majority of process equipment has standard operating manuals and maintenance procedures that are kept in the office file.

The facility ensures that recommended maintenance is performed on process equipment in accordance with manufacturer?s recommendations.  In addition, modifications to existing systems are performed in accordance with manufacturer?s recommendations.  
UST certifies that the propane and other systems were designed in accordance with recognized engineering standards at the time of original construction and during subsequent renovations or modifications.

The propane system was also inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis.  UST follows the manufacturer?s recommendations for maintenance and inspection. Osterman?s leases the tank to UST and maintains the propane system and equipment on an annual basis.  Work orders and inspection checklists for the annual work are maintained as documentation of Osterman?s propane system maintenance.  A safe work permit is completed during these maintenance activities. 
9.0	MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE 
The facility has established and implemented writte

n procedures to manage any change to the facility or to the process chemicals (e.g., introduction of new chemicals).  This procedure is implemented by using the Management of Change forms (MOC) found in Section 9.5 of the RMP.
  
These forms provide a system that evaluates potential changes to the system and potential effects on the process safety operation.  The forms are completed any time there is a change to the process that could affect the overall safety of the chemical system.  There have been changes to the system that include installation of new rotary furnaces and pit furnaces.  These changes have been addressed by updating the PHA and completion of the MOC form.
10.0	PRE-START SAFETY REVIEW 
The facility performs a pre-startup safety review for new or modified facilities.  The checklist found in Section 5 (PHA) of the RMP provides the necessary information to review and evaluate potential modifications to the existing process.  This process is started as soon as possible in the conceptual design of the project.

11.0	COMPLIANCE AUDITS 
Comprehensive compliance audits are performed at least every three years, while some specific programs (e.g., operating procedures, lockout/tagout, etc.) are reviewed annually by the RMPC or his designees.  The facility reviews these latter programs during training.  Periodic audits have been completed on September 1, 2004 and November 2, 2007
12.0	INCIDENT INVESTIGATION 
The facility investigates every incident that results in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals within 48 hours of the incident.  The standard investigation system for evaluating these types of accidents is included in Section 12.4 of the RMP.  This includes an investigation form that must be completed at the time of the accident.

Upon completion of this activity, a group of individuals investigates and determines why the accident took place.  Recommendations for corrective actions are provid

ed, implemented, and documented.  This minimizes the potential for reoccurrence of future similar accidents.
13.0	EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
Employees are one of the key components in safety management systems.  The facility involves employees for the implementation of this plan as follows:

* Employees are involved in safety procedure development and the PHA
* Employees are provided periodic training at regular safety meetings
* Safety meetings empower employees to recommend and implement corrective actions
* A process has been implemented to consider employee recommendations
Employee recommendations are incorporated into H&S procedures, where applicable.  Safety committee activities are documented to ensure employee participation with RMP requirements.
14.0	HOT WORK PERMITS 
This system provides a process whereby each heat producing work activity is evaluated and controlled to prevent fires.  Efforts are made to ensure that the entire facility completes hot work permits if the activity is outside a dedicated fire protected areas (e.g. shop).  This minimizes the potential for catastrophic fires that could affect the propane process.  The instruction and permits can be found in Section 14.0 of the RMP.  UST maintains hot work permits on file for all hot work performed in the facility outside dedicated maintenance areas.
15.0	CONTRACTORS
The facility informs contract employers of the potential hazards of the process and ensures that they are properly trained.  Before working in and around hazardous processes, these contractors are provided the facility?s safety requirements and notification forms found in Section 15.0 of the RMP.
16.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  
Employers must establish and implement a plan that deals with emergency situations at the facility to include the handling of small chemical releases.
